question:
During the framing of the Indian Constitution, the Constituent Assembly held a total of eleven sessions, with sittings spread over for how many days?

SSC MTS 13/11/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The Constituent Assembly of India held its first meeting on 9th December 1946.
  • It conducted 11 sessions in total, concluding on 26th November 1949, when the Constitution was adopted.
  • These sessions took place over 165 days of actual sittings.
  • Members of the Constituent Assembly were elected by the Provincial Legislative Assemblies.
  • The Assembly functioned as both the legislature and constitution-drafting body during this period.

Additional Information:

  • The Constitution of India came into effect on 26th January 1950.
  • Dr. B.R. Ambedkar was the Chairman of the Drafting Committee.
  • Dr. Rajendra Prasad served as the President of the Constituent Assembly.
  • The original Constitution had 395 Articles, 22 Parts, and 8 Schedules.

question:
The Indian Constitution has established _________.

SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The Indian Constitution has established an independent judiciary that functions separately from the legislature and executive.
  • This ensures the separation of powers, a core principle of democratic governance.
  • The Supreme Court is the apex judicial authority, followed by High Courts and Subordinate Courts.
  • Judges are appointed through a defined process and enjoy security of tenure and fixed salaries, ensuring independence.
  • Judicial review empowers courts to invalidate laws or actions that violate the Constitution.

Additional Information:

  • Article 50 of the Directive Principles calls for the separation of judiciary from the executive in the public services of the State.
  • The Supreme Court of India was established on 26 January 1950.
  • India follows a single integrated judiciary, not a dual system like the USA, where federal and state courts are completely separate.

question:
Who among the following, while praising the amending feature of the Indian Constitution said that ‘This variety in the amending process is wise but is rarely found’?

SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• K.C. Wheare, a noted constitutional expert, praised the amending process of the Indian Constitution.
  • He observed that the Indian Constitution has a unique combination of rigid and flexible features regarding amendments.
  • According to him, the variety in the amending process—where some parts can be amended by a simple majority and others require a special procedure—is rarely found in other constitutions.
  • This balanced approach allows adaptability while preserving core principles.

Additional Information:

  • Article 368 deals with the amendment procedure of the Constitution.
  • There are three types of amendments in India:
    1. By simple majority of Parliament
    2. By special majority of Parliament
    3. By special majority with ratification by half of the state legislatures
  • This combination provides flexibility and stability in constitutional evolution.

question:
Which of the following is NOT a feature of the Constitution of India?

SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
option_4: Blend of rigidity & flexibility
solution:
• The Constitution of India provides for single citizenship, meaning all Indians are citizens of India, regardless of the state or union territory they belong to.
  • Unlike countries like the USA, which follow the dual citizenship model (citizenship of both the country and the state), India does not recognize dual citizenship in this manner.
  • Therefore, option (c) Dual Citizenship is NOT a feature of the Indian Constitution.

Additional Information:

  • Universal Adult Franchise: Every citizen above 18 years has the right to vote (Article 326).
  • Independent Judiciary: Ensures the separation of powers and protects fundamental rights.
  • Blend of Rigidity & Flexibility: The Constitution can be amended easily in some areas and with difficulty in others, making it partly rigid and partly flexible.

question:
Which of the following statements are INCORRECT vis-à-vis features of the Indian Constitution?

The Constitution empowers the Prime Minister to proclaim three types of emergencies.

2) A reservation policy is there to uplift the disadvantaged sections of society.

3) The Supreme Court has no power of judicial review.

4) The Constitution provides for universal adult suffrage.

SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• Statement 1 – Incorrect: The power to proclaim emergencies (National, State, Financial) lies with the President, not the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister may advise, but the formal authority is with the President under Articles 352, 356, and 360.
  • Statement 2 – Correct: The Constitution allows for reservation policies (Articles 15(4), 15(5), and 16(4)) to promote the welfare of socially and educationally backward classes, SCs, STs, and others.
  • Statement 3 – Incorrect: The Supreme Court has the power of judicial review under Articles 13, 32, and 136, allowing it to strike down unconstitutional laws.
  • Statement 4 – Correct: Universal Adult Suffrage is provided under Article 326, allowing all citizens aged 18 and above to vote.

Correct Answer: (a) 1 and 3

Additional Information:

  • There are three types of emergencies:
    1. National Emergency – Article 352
    2. President’s Rule (State Emergency) – Article 356
    3. Financial Emergency – Article 360
  • The Supreme Court is also the guardian of the Constitution and protector of fundamental rights.

question:
Which of the following statement(s) is/are INCORRECT vis-a-vis features of the Indian Constitution?

Though India has a federal system, the Constitution does not mention the word 'federation'.

2) Article 5 of the Constitution says that the Parliament by law can create a new state.

3) On the subjects in the Union list, each State Legislature can enact laws for the State.

4) Both the Parliament and State Legislature can pass laws on subjects in concurrent list.

SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• Statement 1 – Correct: The word 'Federation' is indeed not mentioned in the Indian Constitution. Instead, the term used is 'Union of States' (Article 1). Hence, this statement is correct.
  • Statement 2 – Incorrect: Article 5 deals with citizenship at the commencement of the Constitution, not with the creation of new states. The correct article for creating new states is Article 3, not Article 5.
  • Statement 3 – Incorrect: On subjects in the Union List, only the Parliament can make laws. State Legislatures have no authority to legislate on Union List subjects.
  • Statement 4 – Correct: On subjects in the Concurrent List, both the Parliament and State Legislatures can make laws. In case of conflict, Parliament's law prevails (Article 254).

Correct Answer: (b) 2 and 3

Additional Information:

  • Article 3 empowers Parliament to create new states, alter boundaries, or rename them.
  • Union List includes matters of national importance such as defense, foreign affairs, and currency.
  • Concurrent List includes subjects like education, forest, marriage, etc., on which both Centre and States can legislate.

question:
The Indian Constitution came into force on ___ and is celebrated as Republic Day.

SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The Constitution of India was adopted on 26th November 1949, but it came into force on 26th January 1950.
  • This date was selected as it commemorated the Declaration of Purna Swaraj (Complete Independence) made by the Indian National Congress in its Lahore Session of 1930.
  • The enforcement of the Constitution on this day marked India’s transformation into a sovereign republic.
  • Dr. Rajendra Prasad took oath as the first President of India on this day, and the Governor-General's post was abolished.

Additional Information:

  • The Constitution took 2 years, 11 months, and 18 days to be drafted.
  • The original Constitution had 395 Articles, divided into 22 Parts and 8 Schedules.
  • Republic Day is celebrated annually on 26th January with a grand parade at Rajpath (now Kartavya Path) in New Delhi.

question:
Secularism is a feature of the Indian Constitution, which means:

SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (1st shift)
option_1: The State does not promote any religion.
option_2: The State promotes the religion of the minority community.
option_3: The State promotes the religion of the majority community.
option_4: The State can promote any religion.
solution:
• Secularism, as enshrined in the Preamble of the Indian Constitution, means that the State has no official religion.
  • The Indian State maintains neutrality toward all religions and does not favor, promote, or interfere in religious affairs.
  • Citizens are free to profess, practice, and propagate any religion under Article 25.
  • Thus, the State does not promote any religion, ensuring equal treatment of all faiths.

Additional Information:

  • The word ‘Secular’ was added to the Preamble by the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976.
  • India follows the principle of “Sarva Dharma Sambhava” (equal respect for all religions).
  • The Constitution guarantees freedom of religion as a Fundamental Right under Articles 25 to 28.

question:
In which year did the Indian Constitution declare Hindi in Devanagari script to be the official language of the Union?

SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (4th shift)
solution:
• Article 343(1) of the Indian Constitution states that the official language of the Union shall be Hindi in the Devanagari script.
  • This provision was adopted on 14th September 1949 by the Constituent Assembly.
  • Hence, 1949 is the year when Hindi in Devanagari script was declared as the official language of the Union of India.
  • The date, 14th September, is now observed as Hindi Diwas every year.

Additional Information:

  • Though Hindi was declared the official language in 1949, English continued to be used for official purposes for 15 years, as per Article 343(2).
  • Later, through the Official Languages Act, 1963, English was allowed to continue indefinitely for official use along with Hindi.
  • India does not have a national language; it has 22 official languages listed in the 8th Schedule of the Constitution.

question:
The Preamble of the Constitution describes India as:

SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• The Preamble of the Indian Constitution declares India to be a Sovereign, Socialist, Secular, Democratic Republic.
  • The term ‘Secular’ was added by the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976.
  • Secularism in the Indian context means that the State does not favor or promote any religion, and treats all religions equally.
  • Thus, India is constitutionally defined as a secular state.

Additional Information:

  • The Preamble acts as an introductory statement that reflects the core values and guiding principles of the Constitution.
  • It was adopted on 26th November 1949 and came into effect on 26th January 1950.
  • Other key terms in the Preamble include Justice, Liberty, Equality, and Fraternity.

question:
Which of the following word sequences is correct as per the Preamble to the Constitution?

SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (3rd shift)
option_1: Sovereign, socialist, secular, democratic, republic
option_2: Secular, democratic, secular, socialist, sovereign
option_3: Sovereign, secular, socialist, democratic, republic
option_4: Socialist, secular, democratic, republic, sovereign
solution:
• The Preamble to the Constitution of India declares the nation as a:

    "Sovereign, Socialist, Secular, Democratic, Republic."

  • This sequence is the official and correct order as per the Preamble text.
  • The words ‘Socialist’ and ‘Secular’ were inserted into the Preamble by the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976.
  • The Preamble outlines the core values and political philosophy upon which the Constitution is based.

Correct word sequence as per Preamble:

Sovereign → Socialist → Secular → Democratic → Republic

Additional Information:

  • Sovereign: India is independent and not subject to any external authority.
  • Socialist: Commitment to social and economic equality.
  • Secular: Equal treatment of all religions by the State.
  • Democratic: Power rests with the people; elected representatives govern.
  • Republic: The head of the State is elected, not hereditary.

question:
In which of the following years was the National Anthem adopted in its Hindi version by the Constituent Assembly?

SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The National Anthem of India, "Jana Gana Mana", was originally composed in Bengali by Rabindranath Tagore in 1911.
  • The Hindi version of "Jana Gana Mana" was officially adopted by the Constituent Assembly on 24th January 1950.
  • This was two days before the Constitution came into force (26th January 1950).
  • Hence, the correct year of adoption is 1950.

Additional Information:

  • The playing time of the full National Anthem is 52 seconds.
  • Only the first stanza of Tagore’s original composition is recognized as the National Anthem.
  • Along with the National Anthem, the National Song "Vande Mataram" was also given official status on the same day.

question:
When was the ‘The Objective Resolution’ moved by Pt. Jawahar Lal Nehru?

SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• The Objective Resolution was a historic document that laid down the philosophical and ideological framework of the Indian Constitution.
  • It was moved by Pt. Jawahar Lal Nehru in the Constituent Assembly on 13th December 1946.
  • This resolution outlined the vision of independent India, emphasizing justice, equality, liberty, sovereignty, and the safeguarding of minorities and backward sections.
  • The Objective Resolution later became the basis of the Preamble to the Constitution.

Additional Information:

  • The Resolution was adopted on 22nd January 1947 after detailed discussions.
  • It emphasized that India would be an independent sovereign republic.
  • Many of its ideals were reflected in the final Preamble, which begins with "We, the people of India..."

question:
Which of the following is NOT a basic feature of the Indian Constitution?

SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (1st shift)
option_2: Blend of rigidity and flexibility
option_4: Drawn from one source
solution:
• The Indian Constitution is known for incorporating features from multiple sources, including:
    • Britain (Parliamentary system, Rule of Law),
    • USA (Fundamental Rights, Judicial Review),
    • Canada (Federation with strong Centre),
    • Ireland (Directive Principles of State Policy), etc.
  • Therefore, the statement that it is “drawn from one source” is incorrect.
  • This is not a basic feature of the Indian Constitution.

Other options are correct features:

  • Parliamentary system: Adopted from the UK; executive is accountable to the legislature.
  • Blend of rigidity and flexibility: Some provisions can be amended easily, while others need special procedures.
  • Lengthiest written Constitution: With over 450 Articles, it is the most detailed constitution in the world.

Additional Information:

  • The basic structure doctrine was established by the Kesavananda Bharati case (1973).
  • Some key basic features include:
    • Supremacy of the Constitution
    • Rule of Law
    • Judicial Review
    • Secularism
    • Federalism
    • Separation of Powers

question:
Which of the following statements are correct in the context of the Indian Constitution?

There are three major organs of the government, namely Legislature, Executive and Judiciary.

2. A separation of functions rather than powers is followed.

3. All organs of the government are independent.

SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• Statement 1 – Correct: The Indian government is based on the division of responsibilities among three major organs — Legislature, Executive, and Judiciary.
    • The Legislature makes laws, the Executive enforces them, and the Judiciary interprets them.
  • Statement 2 – Correct: India follows a separation of functions, not strict separation of powers.
    • For instance, in the parliamentary system, ministers are part of both the Executive and Legislature.
  • Statement 3 – Incorrect: All organs are not fully independent.
    • While the Judiciary is independent, the Executive and Legislature are interconnected, especially in a parliamentary democracy.

Additional Information:

  • The Constitution ensures checks and balances among the three organs to prevent misuse of power.
  • Judiciary's independence is protected through constitutional provisions like security of tenure and immunity from executive interference.
  • This structure ensures cooperation with accountability, preserving democratic functioning.

question:
Who called the preamble of the Indian Constitution 'The Political Horoscope of our Constitution'?

Matriculation Level 21/06/2024 (Shift- 1)
option_2: Sir Alladi Krishnaswamy Iyer
solution:
• Dr. K.M. Munshi, a prominent member of the Constituent Assembly, referred to the Preamble of the Indian Constitution as the “Political Horoscope of our Constitution.”
  • By this, he meant that the Preamble gives a broad overview of the Constitution’s spirit, ideals, and objectives, much like a horoscope gives insights into a person’s character and destiny.
  • The Preamble reflects the core philosophy and vision guiding the Constitution.

Additional Information:

  • The Preamble declares India to be a Sovereign, Socialist, Secular, Democratic Republic and aims to secure Justice, Liberty, Equality, and Fraternity for its citizens.
  • Though not legally enforceable, the Preamble is considered a key to understanding the Constitution.
  • The 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976 added the words ‘Socialist’ and ‘Secular’ to the Preamble.

question:
When was the preamble to the Indian Constitution amended?

Matriculation Level 26/06/2024 (Shift- 1)
solution:
• The Preamble of the Indian Constitution was amended only once since its adoption.
  • This amendment took place through the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976.
  • The amendment added three important words to the Preamble:
    • Socialist
    • Secular
    • Integrity
  • These additions reflected the ideological commitment of the State during the period of the Emergency under Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

Additional Information:

  • The 42nd Amendment is often referred to as the “Mini Constitution” due to the extensive changes it made to the Constitution.
  • Despite being symbolic, the Preamble holds immense interpretative value, especially in constitutional interpretation by courts.
  • The Preamble was originally adopted on 26th November 1949 and came into force on 26th January 1950.

question:
When is Constitution Day observed in India?

Higher Secondary 24/06/2024 (Shift- 2)
solution:
• Constitution Day (also known as Samvidhan Divas) is observed in India on 26th November every year.
  • This day marks the adoption of the Constitution of India by the Constituent Assembly on 26th November 1949.
  • However, the Constitution came into full effect later, on 26th January 1950, which is celebrated as Republic Day.

Additional Information:

  • Constitution Day was officially declared in 2015 by the Government of India to commemorate Dr. B.R. Ambedkar's contribution as the chief architect of the Constitution.
  • Before 2015, 26th November was observed as Law Day by legal institutions.
  • The day is celebrated in schools, colleges, and government institutions to promote constitutional values and awareness among citizens.

question:
Who among the following is called 'Father of Indian constitution'?

Graduate Level 26/06/2024 (Shift- 3)
solution:
• Dr. Bhim Rao Ambedkar is widely regarded as the “Father of the Indian Constitution.”
  • He was the Chairman of the Drafting Committee, formed on 29 August 1947, which was entrusted with drafting the Constitution of India.
  • Dr. Ambedkar played a crucial role in shaping the structure, philosophy, and content of the Constitution.
  • His knowledge of law, economics, and social justice made him the most influential figure in the drafting process.

Additional Information:

  • The Drafting Committee had 7 members, with Dr. Ambedkar as its head.
  • He is also known for championing social equality and the rights of Dalits and marginalized communities.
  • The Constitution was adopted on 26th November 1949 and came into effect on 26th January 1950.

question:
Who was the designer of India’s national flag?

Graduate Level 26/06/2024 (Shift- 4)
option_4: Prem Behari Narain Raizada
solution:
• Pingali Venkayya, a freedom fighter from Andhra Pradesh, is credited as the designer of India’s national flag.
  • He presented the design to Mahatma Gandhi in 1921, which initially had a spinning wheel (charkha) at the center.
  • The design underwent modifications, and the Ashoka Chakra (24-spoke wheel) replaced the spinning wheel in the final version.
  • The Constituent Assembly adopted the national flag in its present form on 22 July 1947, just before India’s independence.

Additional Information:

  • The national flag has three horizontal stripes:
    • Saffron (top): Courage and sacrifice
    • White (middle): Peace and truth, with the Ashoka Chakra in navy blue
    • Green (bottom): Faith and chivalry
  • The Ashoka Chakra was taken from the Lion Capital of Ashoka at Sarnath.

question:
Who among the following personalities was appointed as the legal advisor of the Constituent Assembly that drafted the document of the Constitution

SSC CHSL 02/08/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• B.N. Rau (Benegal Narsing Rau) was appointed as the legal advisor to the Constituent Assembly in 1946.
  • He played a crucial role in preparing the initial draft of the Indian Constitution, which was later submitted to the Drafting Committee.
  • While Dr. B.R. Ambedkar was the Chairman of the Drafting Committee, it was B.N. Rau who laid the foundational legal framework.

Additional Information:

  • B.N. Rau studied various constitutions around the world (USA, UK, Ireland, Canada, Australia, etc.) to help guide the drafting process.
  • His draft served as the basis for the work of the Drafting Committee, which further developed the final version.
  • He was later appointed as a Judge of the International Court of Justice.

question:
The original Constitution of India was hand written in English by:

SSC CHSL 07/08/2023 (3rd shift)
option_2: Prem Behari Narayan Raizada
solution:
• The original Constitution of India was handwritten in English by Prem Behari Narayan Raizada, a master calligrapher.
  • He wrote the entire document in italic style calligraphy using indigenous ink and handmade paper.
  • Despite the immense effort involved, he refused any payment, and only requested that his name be inscribed on each copy.

Additional Information:

  • The Hindi version of the Constitution was handwritten by Vasant Krishan Vaidya.
  • The final copies were signed by all members of the Constituent Assembly on 24 January 1950, just two days before the Constitution came into effect.
  • Both the English and Hindi versions were decoratively illustrated by artists from Shantiniketan, under the guidance of Nandalal Bose.

question:
Who among the following personalities was the chief draftsman of the constituent assembly that drafted the document of the Constitution?

SSC CHSL 07/08/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• S.N. Mukherjee (S.N. Mukerji) served as the chief draftsman of the Constituent Assembly during the framing of the Indian Constitution.
  • He was responsible for putting into proper legal language the discussions, decisions, and provisions framed by the Drafting Committee.
  • His work ensured that the language of the Constitution was precise, legally sound, and consistent throughout the document.

Additional Information:

  • S.N. Mukherjee worked closely under the guidance of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar, Chairman of the Drafting Committee.
  • His contribution was technical and vital, though not as publicly recognized as other leaders.
  • The clarity and structure of the Constitution owe a great deal to his drafting and legal formulation skills.

question:
Who among the following wrote in calligraphic style the Hindi version of the original Indian Constitution?

SSC CHSL 10/08/2023 (2nd shift)
option_2: Prem Behari Narain Raizada
solution:
• The Hindi version of the original Indian Constitution was handwritten in calligraphic style by Vasant Krishan Vaidya.
  • He was a skilled calligrapher entrusted with transcribing the entire Hindi text in an elegant and formal script.
  • His work complemented that of Prem Behari Narain Raizada, who handwrote the English version of the Constitution.

Additional Information:

  • The artistic design and illustrations of both the Hindi and English versions were done by artists from Shantiniketan, under the leadership of Nandalal Bose.
  • The final handwritten versions were signed by the members of the Constituent Assembly on 24 January 1950.
  • These original copies are preserved in helium-filled cases in the Parliament of India Library.

question:
The structural part of the Indian Constitution is, to a large extent, derived from the Act of _____________.

SSC CHSL 14/08/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• The structural part of the Indian Constitution is largely derived from the Government of India Act, 1935.
  • This Act provided the administrative and institutional framework on which many constitutional provisions were based.
  • Features like:
    • Federal structure
    • Provincial autonomy
    • Bicameral legislature
    • Governor’s powers
    • Public Service Commissions
    • Emergency powers

      were directly adopted or adapted from the 1935 Act.

Additional Information:

  • The Government of India Act, 1935 was the last and most comprehensive British legislation before India’s independence.
  • Unlike the Preamble or Fundamental Rights (which came from other sources), the 1935 Act contributed to the governance machinery and legal framework.
  • The Indian Constitution also borrowed features from other countries, but structurally, 1935 remains the primary source.

question:
Which is NOT a unitary feature of the Constitution of India?

Graduate Level 01/08/2022 (Shift- 4)
option_4: Appointment of the Governor by the President
solution:
• A unitary system typically emphasizes centralized authority and minimal power to regional governments.
  • The following are unitary features of the Indian Constitution:
    • Integrated Judicial System: A single judiciary with the Supreme Court at the top, followed by High Courts and Subordinate Courts.
    • Single Citizenship: All Indians are citizens of India only; there is no separate state citizenship.
    • Appointment of Governors by the President: Central control over states through gubernatorial appointments.
  • Bicameral Legislature, however, is not a unitary feature. It refers to the presence of two Houses of Parliament—the Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha—meant to represent both the people and the states.
    • This structure aligns more with a federal feature, giving a platform to state representation at the central level.

Additional Information:

  • India has a quasi-federal system: It has a blend of unitary and federal features.
  • Federal features include: Dual government, written constitution, distribution of powers, and bicameralism.
  • Unitary features include: Strong Centre, single constitution, and All-India services.

question:
Which of the following is NOT a federal feature of the Indian Constitution?

SSC CHSL 27/05/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• Federal features refer to those characteristics of a constitution that promote division of power between the Centre and States, ensuring autonomy of both levels of government.
  • Let’s examine each option:
    • (a) Dual Government: A clear federal feature. India has two levels of government—Union and State.
    • (b) Division of Powers: Another key federal principle. Powers are distributed between Centre and States through Union, State, and Concurrent Lists (Seventh Schedule).
    • (c) All India Services: This is NOT a federal feature. These services (like IAS, IPS) are common to both Centre and States but are controlled by the Union, which goes against the federal principle of complete state autonomy in administration.
    • (d) Written Constitution: A typical federal characteristic. A written document defines the structure and powers of government and is a standard in federal systems.

Additional Information:

  • All India Services are appointed by the Union Public Service Commission (UPSC) and serve both at the central and state levels.
  • Their central control is seen as a unitary bias in India's otherwise quasi-federal structure.

question:
With reference to the Constituent Assembly, which of the following statements is Correct?

SSC CGL 11/04/2022 (Afternoon)
option_1: The Constituent Assembly ratified India’s membership of the Common wealth in May 1947.
option_2: The Constituent Assembly adopted the National Anthem in January 1950.
option_3: The Constituent Assembly adopted the National Song in January 1948.
option_4: The Constituent Assembly adopted the National Flag in July 1949.
solution:
• The Constituent Assembly played a pivotal role not only in framing the Constitution but also in adopting national symbols of independent India.
  • The National Anthem – "Jana Gana Mana" – was officially adopted by the Constituent Assembly on 24th January 1950, just two days before the Constitution came into force on 26th January 1950.

Let’s assess the options:

  • (a) Incorrect – India became a member of the Commonwealth in May 1949, not 1947, and this was not formally ratified by the Constituent Assembly in the way described.
  • (b) Correct – The National Anthem was adopted in January 1950.
  • (c) Incorrect – The National Song "Vande Mataram" was adopted along with the National Anthem on 24th January 1950, not in January 1948.
  • (d) Incorrect – The National Flag was adopted by the Constituent Assembly on 22nd July 1947, not July 1949.

Additional Information:

  • The Constituent Assembly adopted:
    • National Flag: 22 July 1947
    • National Anthem & National Song: 24 January 1950
    • Constitution: 26 November 1949 (came into effect on 26 January 1950)

question:
How many female members were part of the Constituent Assembly that framed the Constitution of India?

SSC CGL 11/04/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• The Constituent Assembly of India consisted of 299 members at the time of the adoption of the Constitution in 1949.
  • Out of these, 15 were women, representing various regions, communities, and ideologies.
  • These women played important roles in debates related to fundamental rights, minority rights, women’s empowerment, and social justice.

Notable female members included:

  • Sarojini Naidu
  • Rajkumari Amrit Kaur
  • Durgabai Deshmukh
  • Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit
  • Hansa Mehta
  • Renuka Ray
  • Begum Aizaz Rasul (the only Muslim woman in the Assembly)

Additional Information:

  • These women contributed significantly despite their small number.
  • They advocated for gender equality, universal suffrage, and social reforms in the Constitution.
  • Their efforts helped lay the foundation for a progressive and inclusive Constitution.

question:
Who was the chairman of the House Committee of the Constituent Assembly of India?

SSC CGL 18/04/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The House Committee of the Constituent Assembly of India was responsible for making arrangements related to the accommodation and facilities for members of the Assembly.
  • B. Pattabhi Sitaramayya, a senior Congress leader and prominent freedom fighter, was appointed as the Chairman of the House Committee.
  • His role was largely administrative, ensuring that members had proper housing, workspace, and logistical support during the Constitution-making process.

Additional Information:

  • B. Pattabhi Sitaramayya was also a member of the Constituent Assembly representing Madras Province.
  • He had earlier contested the Presidency of the Indian National Congress in 1939 (supported by Gandhi) but lost to Subhas Chandra Bose.
  • The Constituent Assembly had several specialized committees such as:
    • Drafting Committee – Dr. B.R. Ambedkar (Chairman)
    • Union Constitution Committee – Jawaharlal Nehru (Chairman)
    • Fundamental Rights Committee – J.B. Kripalani (Chairman)
    • Advisory Committee – Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel (Chairman)

question:
GV Mavalankar was the Chairman of the ______ of the Constituent Assembly of India.

SSC CGL 20/04/2022 (Morning)
option_1: Advisory Committee on Fundamental Rights, Minorities and Tribal and Excluded Areas
option_2: Committee on the Functions
option_3: Order of Business Committee
option_4: Ad hoc Committee on the National Flag
solution:
• G.V. Mavalankar, a distinguished freedom fighter and constitutional expert, served as the Chairman of the Committee on the Functions of the Constituent Assembly.
  • This committee was tasked with defining the roles and procedures of the Constituent Assembly—particularly how it would function as both a constitution-making body and a legislative body.

Other roles of G.V. Mavalankar:

  • He later became the first Speaker of the Lok Sabha after the adoption of the Constitution.
  • He was also known as the “Father of the Lok Sabha” for shaping the traditions of India's parliamentary system.

Additional Information:

  • The Committee on the Functions of the Constituent Assembly ensured a smooth procedural framework during debates, discussions, and decision-making processes.
  • This committee was distinct from other major committees like:
    • Drafting Committee – Dr. B.R. Ambedkar
    • Advisory Committee – Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel
    • Union Constitution Committee – Jawaharlal Nehru
    • National Flag Committee (Ad hoc) – Dr. Rajendra Prasad

question:
The total membership of the Constituent Assembly was 389, of which ______ were representatives of princely states.

SSC CGL 18/08/21 (Evening)
solution:
• The total strength of the Constituent Assembly was originally 389 members.
    • Out of these:
      • 296 members were to be elected from British Indian Provinces.
      • 93 members were to be nominated from the Princely States.
  • The representatives from Princely States were not directly elected but were nominated by the rulers of those states.

Correct breakdown:

  • Total members: 389
  • British Indian Provinces: 296
  • Princely States: 93

Additional Information:

  • After the partition of India in 1947, the number of members in the Constituent Assembly was reduced to 299.
  • The first meeting of the Constituent Assembly was held on 9 December 1946.
  • The Constitution was adopted on 26 November 1949 and came into force on 26 January 1950.

question:
The members of the Constituent Assembly signed the Constitution of India on ______.

SSC CHSL 16/04/21 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The Constitution of India was adopted by the Constituent Assembly on 26 November 1949.
  • However, the members of the Constituent Assembly signed the final handwritten copies of the Constitution on 24 January 1950, two days before it came into force.
  • This signing marked the formal authentication of the document by its framers.

Important Dates to Remember:

  • 26 November 1949 – Constitution was adopted.
  • 24 January 1950 – Constitution was signed by 284 members of the Constituent Assembly.
  • 26 January 1950 – Constitution came into effect, celebrated as Republic Day.

Additional Information:

  • On the same day (24 January 1950), the National Anthem ("Jana Gana Mana") and National Song ("Vande Mataram") were also officially adopted.
  • Dr. Rajendra Prasad was elected the first President of India on this day.

question:
In which year did Motilal Nehru (Chairman) and eight other Congress leaders draft a constitution for India?

SSC CHSL 13/10/2020 (Evening)
solution:
• In 1928, Motilal Nehru, as the Chairman of the All Parties Conference, led a committee of nine members that drafted a constitution for India.
  • This came to be known as the Nehru Report, the first major attempt by Indians to frame a constitutional structure without British input.
  • The report proposed:
    • Dominion status for India within the British Empire.
    • Fundamental rights for citizens.
    • Responsible government at the centre and in provinces.
    • Secular state with no state religion.

Additional Information:

  • The committee included prominent leaders like Subhas Chandra Bose, Tej Bahadur Sapru, and M.R. Jayakar.
  • The Simon Commission (1927), an all-British committee with no Indian member, triggered the need for Indians to present their own constitutional vision.
  • The Nehru Report was rejected by the Muslim League, leading to further divisions in Indian politics.
